entity.name: Maya - Kukulkan
entity.subtitle: K'uk'ulkan- "Feathered Serpent" / "Quetzal-Serpent"
entity.description:
The great feathered serpent is one of the most important deities of Mesoamerica, worshipped from the
                earliest Olmec civilizations through the Maya and Aztec empires. As K'uk'ulkan among the Yucatec Maya
                and Q'uq'umatz among the K'iche', this winged serpent god brought knowledge, civilization, and the
                sacred calendar to humanity. His descent as a serpent of light at Chichen Itza each equinox remains
                one of the world's most spectacular archaeoastronomical phenomena.

mythology_stories.intro: In the K'iche' Maya creation account, Q'uq'umatz (the K'iche' name for Kukulkan) was one of the primordial creator deities who existed before the world began. Together with Tepeu (another creator god), Q'uq'umatz floated upon the primordial waters in the darkness, wrapped in blue-green quetzal feathers.

worship.forms of worship:
• Equinox ceremonies: Gatherings at Chichen Itza to witness the serpent of light
  • Offerings: Jade, quetzal feathers, copal incense, flowers, and food
  • Pilgrimage: Journeys to his major temples and the Sacred Cenote
  • Calendar rituals: Ceremonies marking the cycles he was said to have given humanity
  • Round temples: Circular structures allowing wind (his element) to flow freely

archetype.name: CULTURE HERO
archetype.description: Kukulkan embodies the Culture Hero archetype - bringing civilization, the calendar, writing, and the arts to humanity.
